uation \(\frac{9-4x}{x+6}=7\) for \(x\), we proceed through the following steps:
Clear the fraction by multiplying both sides of the equation by the denominator. (What happens when you multiply both sides by \(x+6\)?)
Simplify the equation after removing the denominator. (Can you express the equation without any fractions?)
Isolate the variable term on one side by moving other terms to the opposite side. (What do you get when you subtract 9 from both sides?)
Simplify further if necessary to get \(x\) alone. (What is the simplified form of the equation now?)
Solve for \(x\). (What value of \(x\) satisfies the simplified equation?)
Check whether the determined value of \(x\) makes the original equation undefined. (Does substituting \(x\) back into the original equation make the denominator zero?)
Verify by substituting the value of \(x\) back into the original equation if it isn't undefined. (Does the left-hand side equal the right-hand side when \(x\) is substituted back?)
